I'm here, you know, with my sweats on and my tennis - it has to be us.
We don't have to wait for someone else to come in and save and do something.

And most of Baltimore stayed indoors.
A kind of salmon that has been genetically modified so it grows faster could soon be in your grocery store.
The Food and Drug Administration approved the fish today.
NPR's Dan Charles reports.
This new kind of fast-growing salmon was actually created 25 years ago.
A new gene was inserted into fertilized salmon eggs.
It boosted production of a fish growth hormone.
The company that did this, AquaBounty Technologies, based in Massachusetts, has been trying to get government approval to sell this fish ever since.
Five years ago, the FDA's scientific advisors concluded that it is safe to eat and won't harm the environment.
Alison Van Eenennaam, a biotechnology specialist at the University of California Davis who was part of that scientific evaluation, says it wasn't a hard decision.
Because basically, nothing in the data suggested that these fish were in any way unsafe or different to the conventional farm-raised salmon.
The FDA now is giving the salmon a green light.
It also says there's no reason why the fish need to be labeled as different from any other salmon.
It is requiring AquaBounty to take precautions to make sure the fish don't get into the ocean where they might compete with or interbreed with wild salmon.
AquaBounty will only be allowed to raise the modified fish in tanks on land at just two sites.
Also, the fish will be sterile.
But that's not enough for the fish's opponents.
This frankenfish, this GMO salmon should not be approved and shouldn't have been approved.
This is Dana Perls, a campaigner with Friends of the Earth.
Perls and other critics of this decision say in the future, GMO fish farms may get bigger.
Mistakes will happen, and fish will escape into the oceans.
To stop it now, they're organizing consumer boycotts.
People do not want to eat this fish.
And it's becoming more and more clear that the majority of consumers won't eat the GMO fish even if it is available.
Perls says already 60 retailers have promised not to sell the fish.
Dan Charles, NPR News.
After 16 years of satirizing politics and the news business, tonight ""Daily Show"" host Jon Stewart says goodbye.
NPR TV critic Eric Deggans takes a look at how ""The Daily Show"" changed the way we look at politics and the media.
Robert Barnett is a powerhouse Washington lawyer who sits at the nexus of politics and media.
He's brokered everything from President Bill Clinton's book deal to NBC News anchor Brian Williams's move to MSNBC.
Many of his high-profile clients have appeared on ""The Daily Show,"" and he laments to its departure.
No.

It does not appeal that anyone - it does not appear that anyone has found the magic key - the Ronald Reagan key, if you will - to bring together the three legs of the Republican coalition, which would be social conservatives, economic conservatives, and what we sometimes call national security or national - international strength conservatives, people who want to talk about projecting a very robust foreign policy.
All of those groups are still looking to a different champion.

And with respect to the social conservatives, while they seem to have recently been coalescing behind Mike Huckabee, there's still a lot of volatility, and people are still taking a long look at Mitt Romney.
Now, tell us exactly how the caucuses work.
Are they different from a primary?
Quite different in that, if you go to a primary, it's just like voting on Election Day.
You walk into your polling place, you pull the lever or you mark your ballot for whomever you prefer and you walk out.
You may have to wait in line, but at least it's over when it's over.
In the caucus situation - quite different.
You have to set aside a whole evening and it's going to be a Thursday night.
Three weeks from tonight, January 3rd in Iowa.
You have to set aside that whole evening.
Go somewhere -it might be a school, it might be some other kind of a public building - and in auditorium or a large room, gather with people who are like-minded, in favor of a particular candidate.
You're going to listen to some speeches and you're going to listen to some people make some pitches, and it's kind of a little bit of a town hall.
And then you stand in a group with the people who prefer your candidate.
And if you have at least 15 percent of the folks in the room, then you are quote, a ""viable group"" or a ""viable caucus.
And that means that your person, whomever you're supporting, gets your support and that gets reported to Des Moines and read out on television out to the world.
If, on the other hand, your candidate is a little below that 15 percent threshold, your candidate disappears and gets nothing.
Now, how does this set the stage for the following primaries?
If you win in Iowa, you look like the person who is the people's choice, at least in one state for one night.
And that is a tremendous boon.
It's much stronger than any poll.
And in certain cases, it has allowed candidates to vault their way all the way to the nomination.
Usually, though, the Iowa choice has to be sorted out against the choices of other states.
So we are having New Hampshire this year, just five days later.
It's not clear yet whether New Hampshire will accept the judgment of Iowa.

If Iowa, for example, were to dismiss Mitt Romney on the Republican side, who has worked very hard for the Iowa vote, that would probably put a bruise on him but not cost him his chance to win New Hampshire, where, after all, he was the governor just across the state line in neighboring Massachusetts where they get their media from.
So Mitt could recover there.
It's possible that Hillary Clinton could lose Iowa to Barack Obama and still make a comeback in New Hampshire.
But it puts a lot of pressure on either of those people if they are to lose Iowa to then bounce back in New Hampshire.
And the polls suggest, right now at least, that New Hampshire is paying some attention to what's going on in Iowa and feeling some of the same trends and pressures.
Well, Ron, thanks for the debrief.
My pleasure.
Good to be with you.
We've been speaking with Ron Elving.
He's the supervising senior Washington editor for NPR.
He joined us from our studios in Washington, D.C.
From NPR New, this is DAY TO DAY.
If you suffered from celebrity withdrawal during the Hollywood writers strike, well, relief is at hand.
This weekend, Sunday night, the 80th annual Academy Awards ceremony.
The Oscars are a bonanza, at least money-wise, for ABC.
It's the second most-watched show on TV after the Super Bowl.
MARKETPLACE's Amy Scott is here now.
And Amy, I understand advertisers have, well, they've spent millions to pay for this show.
Yeah, they have.
People are talking about a lot of pent up demand for the show after the celebrity-free Golden Globes and People's Choice Awards, and a lot of that demand is coming from advertisers.
They spent an average $1.8 million this year on a 30-second spot.
As you said, it's the second most-watched show of the year and advertisers really want to reach that audience.
How many people will be watching?
Well, it's really fluctuated in recent years.
Last year it was about 40 million people.
But 10 years ago, when ""Titanic"" swept the awards, 55 million people tuned in.
And the audience does tend to be lower when the contenders for best picture weren't mega-hits at the box office, which was the case this year.
Juno"" is the only film that grossed more than $100 million.
So while that pent up demand left over from the strike might attract some viewers, many are expecting a smaller audience overall.
What about for the movies that win?
Is there a payout for them?
Does it effect DVD sales?
Well it can be a big boost, even at the box office.
Five years ago the musical ""Chicago"" won best picture.
It added 136 theaters, sales went up 27 percent.
But I spoke with Michael Speier, who's executive editor of Variety.
He says most of this year's films have already had their box-office runs, they've settled on dates for their DVD releases.
You know, there's certainly a bump if you can put that best picture sticker on the box.
But when you're talking about violent movies like ""There Will Be Blood"" and ""No Country for Old Men,"" Speier says this year's crop isn't quite as accessible.
If they win, they certainly have another month to play.
And they could expand, absolutely.
But it's not as if these are movies like ""Chicago"" that can just broadly appeal to the mass audience.
So I don't see a big spike for any of them.
There has been a big spike, though, in the nominal values of the Oscars.
Bloomberg News reports today that the price of each of those gold-plated statues reached $500 this year, which is a 25 percent increase thanks to the gold market.
And of course winning one of those statues can greatly an individual's personal fortunes.
Nicole Kidman's asking price reportedly doubled after she won best actress for ""The Hours"".
All right.
Thank you, Amy.
That's Amy Scott of public radio's daily business show, MARKETPLACE.
This is SCIENCE FRIDAY.
I'm Ira Flatow.

Those guys are gonna come blow you away.
They're gonna kill you.
And we said, no. First thing is you stand up and speak your mind as any normal human being has the right to do.
There was a state of unease throughout the country.
You could feel it.
You could feel that something had to give.
And it happened on June 16.
